Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Optical Sensing and Imaging of Bacterial Infection to Improve Global Health

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration: 1254767(Maitland) Cell culture based methods for the detection and quantification of bacterial pathogens remain the gold standard. However, depending on the pathogen, this method can take anywhere from one day to one month to form colonies and can have high variability and limited sensitivity. The development of genetically-modified fluorescent bacteria for use in whole-animal imaging systems has enabled more rapid quantification of bacterial infection and real-time evaluation of therapeutic agents and vaccines. However, detection of fluorescent bacteria and resolution of regions of infection inside a host animal is limited due to tissue absorption and scattering, especially deep inside the animal, such as in the lungs in the case of tuberculosis. Consequently, a greater number of bacteria are required; however, high dose infections are not physiologically normal. The research proposed here will build on our preliminary work to develop optical fiber based technology to increase sensitivity in whole-animal imaging by bringing a novel diffusing fiber excitation source closer to the pathogen in the lungs, enable high resolution imaging in vivo in the lung co-registered with whole-animal imaging using an innovative miniaturized fiber microendoscope, and sense fluorescent bacteria at unprecedented levels using a diffuser-based probe for excitation with integrated fibers for fluorescence collection. The fiber sensor will be developed to exploit the recent development of a near infrared reporter enzyme fluorescence probe that has potential to be used for sensitive, real-time detection of tuberculosis in humans.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes Report

The goals of this NSF CAREER Award were 1) to develop innovative sensing and imaging technologies for basic science and translational research to improve public health worldwide, and 2) to provide students from all backgrounds with educational, research, and design experiences to enhance their global awareness and engagement. The target application for this research was the use of light for detection and treatment of bacterial infection. The work resulted in six peer-reviewed journals and three proceedings.

OPTICAL IMAGING TOOLS TO STUDY PULMONARY INFECTION

Small animal models are frequently used in the study of disease pathogenesis and for the development of vaccines and drug therapies. In vivo optical imaging of live animals using bacteria that is luminescent, or gives off light, is a relatively new approach to monitor infections over time in the same animal, reducing time, cost, and total number of animals needed for rigorous studies. This strategy is complicated by absorption of light as it travels through the body, particularly in pulmonary infection where target bacteria that convert illumination light to fluorescence signal are deep in the body. To enhance optical detection of low numbers of bacteria in pulmonary infections, we developed an optical imaging strategy that improves sensitivity by two to four orders of magnitude, depending on the fluorescence excitation wavelength. This was accomplished by moving the illumination source inside the airway through a microendoscope inserted through an intratracheal tube. With this enhancement, the level of detection of optical imaging in a mouse model was reduced to approximately 100 colony forming units of mycobacteria, the causative agent of tuberculosis.

COMPUTATIONAL MODEL OF LIGHT TRANSPORT IN THE LUNGS

A computational model of light transport in the lungs was developed to predict the light distribution in the lungs and the detection sensitivity of the optical imaging technique to fluorescent bacteria in the lungs. The model was used to evaluate and optimize the engineering design of the microendoscope without the need to test the device in animals. Additionally, the computational model was used to scale up the torso size to evaluate the capability to use optical imaging to detect tuberculosis in children, a population underserved by the current tuberculosis diagnostic techniques.

3D PRINTED TISSUE PHANTOMS

Various tissue-mimicking phantoms were fabricated to validate the computational model and to test and optimize the optical imaging tools in a more controlled environment. These phantoms were designed to mimic both the optical properties of tissue and the complex structure of the airway within the torso. 3D printing was used to create a branching structure that was immersed in a lung-shaped polymer mold and then dissolved out of the polymer lung phantom to create a mock airway void. A scientific video publication was used to disseminate the step-by-step instructions for the complex tissue phantom fabrication protocol.

COMMERCIAL TRANSLATION OF BLUE LIGHT TECHNOLOGY TO PREVENT INFECTION

A blue-light LED array was designed and prototyped to test the ability of blue light to inactivate methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) with no damage to human cells. Following participation in the NSF I-CORPS program, a company was founded and awarded an NSF SBIR Phase I award to commercialize a flexible blue-light emitting bandage to inactivate bacteria on the skin surface to prevent infections in surgical sites.

STUDY ABROAD EXPERIENCE IN RWANDA

Over 100 engineering undergraduates have traveled to Rwanda for a two-month summer experience offered annually. The first month is spent in intensive language and technical training in the capital city of Kigali, where students live in homestays. The students are paired up and placed in hospitals across the country for the second month. The students repair medical equipment, compile inventory lists, and conduct needs-finding interviews with hospital staff. Based on their interviews and their experience in the clinical environment, participants produce a design proposal for medical or testing devices appropriate for the developing world. This has been a transformative experience for students both personally and professionally.

GLOBAL HEALTH MULTISCIPLINARY RESEARCH AND DESIGN EXPERIENCE

Over 50 engineering undergraduates have participated in problem-based global health multidisciplinary design or research experiences. For the year-long design experiences, student teams consisting of freshmen to senior students from multiple engineering disciplines used the design proposals generated from the Rwanda study abroad program. Students that traveled to Rwanda provided technical, environmental, and societal context for the design problem to the other participants, broadening the global awareness of students. Additionally, engineering undergraduates participated in the laboratory research described in the projects on optical detection, modeling, and treatment of infection described above.
